poem:
**For Sue Jones, Advocate of Harlow**

In thin whispers of light,
Harlow holds your ghost,
Sue, in council halls
and quiet kitchens, advising,
lifting burdens with unseen hands.
Your voice, a murmur
soft as fog, lingers—
a steady pulse in
Essex morning,
town's true champion,
benefits bound in
your gentle touch.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Sue Jones obituary My friend Sue Jones, who has died of cancer aged 67, did enormous good for the people of Harlow in Essex as a welfare rights adviser. Although she was not from Harlow originally, over a period of 40 years she came to imbue the town’s spirit, and became a champion for it. Sue arrived there in the mid-1980s to work as a benefits and employment adviser in the Welfare Rights and Advice". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
